The case, *Sharma vs. Verma*, centered on the inheritance of a property located at 12, Karol Bagh, Delhi, 110005. The court clarified the applicability of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, particularly sections 8 & 14, in determining the rightful heirs. Adv. R.K. Mishra, representing the plaintiff, argued for a broader interpretation of "coparcenary property" to include properties acquired before 1956.

The court clarified the applicability of the Hindu Succession Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty six, particularly sections eight and fourteen, in determining the rightful heirs. Advocate R. K. unnormalised: The judgment highlighted the importance of documentary evidence in establishing ownership. The court emphasized that mere possession, without proper title deeds or registered sale agreements, is insufficient to claim ownership under civil law. The judge, Justice Malhotra, specifically pointed out the absence of a registered will (dated 15/08/1947) as a crucial factor in deciding against the plaintiff. The case involved a complex web of familial relationships and conflicting claims, necessitating a thorough examination of the relevant legal provisions.

It clarified that claiming adverse possession requires continuous and uninterrupted possession for a period exceeding 12 yrs, a standard set by the Limitation Act, 1963. The defendant, represented by Adv. S. Banerjee, successfully demonstrated that their possession was not only continuous but also based on a valid lease agreement (expiring on 31/12/2023).
